posts.name: Naroglu
posts.cooked:
Hope you all having a great day.

My team planning to use Kiwi Drive at the off-season for fun, and I’m trying to write some localization code. I’m having problem in one spot.

Let’s assume that have classic kiwi drive, 3 omni-wheeled and 120 degrees between each wheel,can read encoder values from each wheel, and started with value of 0 tick for each encoder. If robot moves like this and at the end encoder values equals to A = 0 tick, B = 6 tick, C = 6 Tick.

https://imgur.com/a/DO0eF24 ( CD didn’t allow me to upload photo directly)

Will the d value equals to 6 tick, or 6 sin(60), or 12 tick, or 12 sin(60)tick, or something else?

Also, if you have any source for odometry and kinematics (unreleated to the drive base), can you share please?

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: In general, drivetrains with omni or mechanum wheels can’t get good odometry from the drive wheels because of unpredictable friction and slip effects.  This will be particularly true for Kiwi drive.  You will almost certainly need to measure odometry with dead wheels instead.

posts.name: Naroglu
posts.cooked:
Thanks for your response.

Where did you mean by saying “This will be particularly true for Kiwi drive.”?

Did you mean tracking wheels by saying “Dead wheels”?

posts.name: Patrick McNaughton
posts.cooked:
Peter_Johnson:

dead wheels

Was just thinking about this, why don’t we use dead wheels in FRC ? I see them used in FTC (although probably for the reason you just mentioned) Do they offer any advantage over doing normal swerve drive odometry?
Heres a thread that I made asking the same question

link_counts.title: Viability of tracking wheels for better odometry in FRC?

posts.name: guineawheek
posts.cooked:
PatMcN:

why don’t we use dead wheels in FRC ?

Traction. In FRC you get blue nitrile and have pretty consistent grip with the carpet. FTC is played on tiles with a field-damage-test so there’s a limit on how grippy your drivetrain can be, and mecanum fits the same role swerve does in the program. The gains from deadwheels are much more hit or miss in FRC as a result.

posts.name: Kaleb Dodd
Max Morehead
posts.cooked:
I believe Peter is suggesting measuring the movement of the robot directly, instead of relying on sensors on the wheels which change in orientation in relation to the robot.

As for why this might be worse with Kiwi, at all times, at least two of your wheels are sliding, which is typically the hard part to model/measure.

The way I’ve seen this done is to have two Omni wheels touching the ground at 90 degrees to each other. The Omni wheels should be spring loaded so they maintain good contact with the ground.

1986’s 2017 reveal video has an example.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
Unfortunately some links are broken, Ether laid this stuff out well.

Kiwi Field Oriented Driving Programming Technical Discussion

posts.name: sam liu
posts.cooked:
A silly way to do it is by having a WPILib Swerve Drive Odometry that has three swerve modules.  When you update the odometry, keep the module’s facings dead.

Also, I stand with

How Should Kiwi Drive Localization Kinematics Be? Control System

If you think about how Kiwi Drives works, they are skidding all the time .

link_counts.title: Swerve Drive Odometry — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Naroglu
posts.cooked: Thank you. Thank you so so much that i don’t know how to explain it with words. I searched on CD and didn’t came across with that discussion.

posts.name: Naroglu
posts.cooked: Thank you so much, I will mention your team and this github link in our github and engineering portfolio. Do you have any sources that i can browse / learn “Vect” library?

posts.name: Kaleb Dodd
posts.cooked:
Yeah it is in the util section for that robots code

2015-Simbot-SideSwipe/src/org/simbotics/simbot2015/util/Vect.java at master · Simbotics/2015-Simbot-SideSwipe · GitHub

It’s just a class made to handle common functions for vector math.
